Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track 2: Molecular Brain Connectomics: from Genes to Cognition
Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award brings together research areas traditionally supported in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems in the Directorate for Biological Sciences, in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering,Environmental, and Transport Systems in the Directorate for Engineering, and in the Division of Behavior and Cognitive Sciences in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences. Cognition arises from the activity within complex brain circuits. These brain circuits are laid out according to a species' genetic blueprint. Past and current successes in uncovering the biological basis of cognition include the discovery of areas in the human brain supporting specific cognitive functions, the determination of the roles that specific cell types play in the behavior of animals like the mouse, and the increasingly detailed understanding of the impact specific genes and their alterations can have on cognitive functions in health and disease. The goal of this interdisciplinary project, conducted at The Rockefeller University, is to directly determine the genetic specificity of brain circuit elements that are critically important for high-level cognitive function. This project will be significant by 1) elucidating the complexity of biological organization from the level of genes, through cell types, brain areas, and neural circuits to behavior, 2) developing new technology that will allow researchers to dissect brain circuits underlying cognition with the precision and specificity of model organisms, and 3) improving the understanding of how genetic alterations impact cognition. The interdisciplinary project at the interface of cognitive neuroscience, neural systems, and neurotechnology, is expected to have broader impacts on society by providing insights into some of the deepest questions about the human mind and by offering unique educational and outreach opportunities to improve public understanding of the organization and function of the brain.

The project will investigate the genetic specificity of a multi-node brain circuit that supports cognitive function. The circuit will be localized with functional and structural magnetic brain imaging. Genetic expression patterns of projection neurons within multiple circuit nodes will then be determined using cutting edge molecular techniques. The functions of the projection neurons linking the nodes will then be determined through advanced and custom-designed optogenetic and electrophysiological techniques. The same optogenetic approach will then be used for causal interrogation of projection neurons in cognitive and emotional behaviors. Combining the gene expression and functional data, predictions for how specific polymorphisms in human genes may alter cognitive-emotional abilities will be generated. These predictions will be tested through functional brain imaging and behavioral testing of genotyped subjects. Together, these investigations will provide deep insights into the brain circuits and genetic underpinnings that make possible the cognitive functions of the human mind.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the brain to execute any function - be it seeing, thinking, remembering, or planning actions – it must coordinate processes across multiple brain areas. There is only one way for brain areas to interact, and that is through long range connections. These connections are formed by a particular cell class, projection neurons. Understanding some of their functions and their genetic specificity, was the overarching goal of this project.  We focused on the social brain, because prior research suggested a specific vulnerability of projection neurons of the social brain in the autism spectrum disorders.

To address these questions, we used a combination of techniques that are typically used in different studies. To begin to uncover what kinds of messages projection neurons are sending, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) of whole brains to localize regions specialized on the processing of faces. We focused on three such brain regions (called ML, AL, and AM) we knew from our own prior research form a processing chain that transforms information coming from the eye in three steps. But could information also be sent backwards? The connections between these areas suggested it should. We designed an experiment in which the content of an upcoming picture could be predicted from the content of the preceding picture. But in a small number of cases, we broke this expectation and presented a surprise second picture. When that happened, activity in ML was increased. We could measure this ‘expectation violation’ signal in great detail by measuring activity with small recording electrodes directly from individual cells. Analyzing exactly how each cell’s ‘expectation violation’ signal was shaped, we found that it had the key properties of high-level areas AL and AM, and not of low-level area ML – despite the fact the signal occurred in ML. Thus this signal, in all likelihood, must be sent via projection neurons in AM and AL back to ML, where it generates predictions that help this region process information more efficiently.

To determine the genetic specificity of projection neurons, we focused on a specific part of the emotional brain and a group of projection neurons that have been implicated in depression. We labeled these neurons with a virus that travels backwards from the site of injection along the long-range connections to the body of the projection cell. We constructed the virus specifically in a way that it would capture the messenger molecules of genes that are actively expressed within the cell body. Sequencing these messengers, we were able to identify a repertoire of genes unique for the projection neuron populations compared to other types of cells in the same region. Further, we repeated these experiments across species and found that the basic molecular signature of projection neurons is largely conserved. The genetic data generated by this project can now be cross-referenced with databases of genes implicated in human brain disorders to elucidate cell type-specific molecular pathways that can be targeted for novel therapeutics to treat disease.

Projection neurons form a bottle neck for information transmission. If their functions are impaired, so will complex operations of the brain that are particularly important in the social domain. At the same time, because information needs to be funneled through these bottle-necks, they allow for particularly important insights into brain function. Together, our findings and the new approach we established towards understanding the genetic backbone and the functions of social and emotional brain circuits in complex brains, pave the way to a deeper understanding of exactly what messages are exchanged between brain areas during mental operations, and how they might be altered in neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders.
